news_summary: Today's space news highlights exciting advancements in planetary exploration and understanding, including discoveries about extreme exoplanet atmospheres, innovative mission operations for the Moon and Mars, insights into the solar system's formation influenced by stellar explosions, and new findings on galaxy and black hole relationships.
news_summary_fr: L'actualité spatiale d'aujourd'hui met en lumière des avancées passionnantes dans l'exploration et la compréhension des planètes, notamment des découvertes sur les atmosphères extrêmes d'exoplanètes, des missions innovantes pour la Lune et Mars, des connaissances sur la formation du système solaire influencée par des explosions stellaires et de nouvelles découvertes sur les relations entre galaxies et trous noirs.
news_summary_es: Las noticias espaciales de hoy destacan emocionantes avances en la exploración y comprensión planetarias, incluidos descubrimientos sobre atmósferas extremas de exoplanetas, innovadoras operaciones de misiones para la Luna y Marte, conocimientos sobre la formación del sistema solar influida por explosiones estelares y nuevos hallazgos sobre las relaciones entre galaxias y agujeros negros.

articles.title: NASA’s Webb Detects Thick Atmosphere Around Broiling Lava World
articles.summary: Researchers using NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope have detected the strongest evidence yet for an atmosphere on a rocky planet outside our solar system, as NASA leads the world in exploring the universe from the Moon to Mars and beyond. Observations of the ultra-hot super-Earth TOI-561 b suggest that the exoplanet is surrounded by a […]
articles.content:
Researchers using NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope have detected the strongest evidence yet for an atmosphere on a rocky planet outside our solar system, as NASA leads the world in exploring the universe from the Moon to Mars and beyond. Observations of the ultra-hot super-Earth TOI-561 b suggest that the exoplanet is surrounded by a thick blanket of gases above a global magma ocean. The results help explain the planet’s unusually low density and challenge the prevailing wisdom that relatively small planets so close to their stars are not able to sustain atmospheres.

Image A: Super-Earth Exoplanet TOI-561 b and Its Star (Artist's Concept)

This artist’s concept shows what the hot super-Earth exoplanet TOI-561 b and its star could look like based on observations from NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope and other observatories. Webb data suggests that the planet is surrounded by a thick atmosphere above a magma ocean. Illustration: NASA, ESA, CSA, Ralf Crawford (STScI)

With a radius roughly 1.4 times Earth’s, and an orbital period less than 11 hours, TOI-561 b falls into a rare class of objects known as ultra-short period exoplanets. Although its host star is only slightly smaller and cooler than the Sun, TOI-561 b orbits so close to the star — less than one million miles (one-fortieth the distance between Mercury and the Sun) — that it must be tidally locked, with the temperature of its permanent dayside far exceeding the melting temperature of typical rock.

“What really sets this planet apart is its anomalously low density,” said Johanna Teske, staff scientist at Carnegie Science Earth and Planets Laboratory and lead author on a paper published Thursday in The Astrophysical Journal Letters. “It’s not a super-puff, but it is less dense than you would expect if it had an Earth-like composition.”

Image B: Super-Earth Exoplanet TOI-561 b (Artist's Concept)

An artist’s concept shows what a thick atmosphere above a vast magma ocean on exoplanet TOI-561 b could look like. Measurements captured by NASA's James Webb Space Telescope suggest that in spite of the intense radiation it receives from its star, TOI-561 b is not a bare rock. Illustration: NASA, ESA, CSA, Ralf Crawford (STScI)

One explanation the team considered for the planet’s low density was that it could have a relatively small iron core and a mantle made of rock that is not as dense as rock within Earth. Teske notes that this could make sense: “TOI-561 b is distinct among ultra-short period planets in that it orbits a very old (twice as old as the Sun), iron-poor star in a region of the Milky Way known as the thick disk. It must have formed in a very different chemical environment from the planets in our own solar system.” The planet's composition could be representative of planets that formed when the universe was relatively young.

But an exotic composition can’t explain everything. The team also suspected that TOI-561 b might be surrounded by a thick atmosphere that makes it look larger than it actually is. Although small planets that have spent billions of years baking in blazing stellar radiation are not expected to have atmospheres, some show signs that they are not just bare rock or lava.

To test the hypothesis that TOI-561 b has an atmosphere, the team used Webb’s NIRSpec (Near-Infrared Spectrograph) to measure the planet’s dayside temperature based on its near-infrared brightness. The technique, which involves measuring the decrease in brightness of the star-planet system as the planet moves behind the star, is similar to that used to search for atmospheres in the TRAPPIST-1 system and on other rocky worlds.

If TOI-561 b is a bare rock with no atmosphere to carry heat around to the nightside, its dayside temperature should be approaching 4,900 degrees Fahrenheit (2,700 degrees Celsius). But the NIRSpec observations show that the planet’s dayside appears to be closer to 3,200 degrees Fahrenheit (1,800 degrees Celsius) — still extremely hot, but far cooler than expected.

Image C: Super-Earth Exoplanet TOI-561 b (NIRSpec Emission Spectrum)

An emission spectrum captured by NASA's James Webb Space Telescope in May 2024 shows the brightness of different wavelengths of near-infrared light emitted by exoplanet TOI-561 b. Comparing the data to models suggests that the planet is surrounded by a volatile-rich atmosphere. Illustration: NASA, ESA, CSA, Ralf Crawford (STScI); Science: Johanna Teske (Carnegie Science Earth and Planets Laboratory), Anjali Piette (University of Birmingham), Tim Lichtenberg (Groningen), Nicole Wallack (Carnegie Science Earth and Planets Laboratory)

To explain the results, the team considered a few different scenarios. The magma ocean could circulate some heat, but without an atmosphere, the nightside would probably be solid, limiting flow away from the dayside. A thin layer of rock vapor on the surface of the magma ocean is also possible, but on its own would likely have a much smaller cooling effect than observed.

“We really need a thick volatile-rich atmosphere to explain all the observations,” said Anjali Piette, coauthor from the University of Birmingham, United Kingdom.

“Strong winds would cool the dayside by transporting heat over to the nightside. Gases like water vapor would absorb some wavelengths of near-infrared light emitted by the surface before they make it all the way up through the atmosphere. (The planet would look colder because the telescope detects less light.) It’s also possible that there are bright silicate clouds that cool the atmosphere by reflecting starlight.”

While the Webb observations provide compelling evidence for such an atmosphere, the question remains: How can a small planet exposed to such intense radiation can hold on to any atmosphere at all, let alone one so substantial? Some gases must be escaping to space, but perhaps not as efficiently as expected.

“We think there is an equilibrium between the magma ocean and the atmosphere. At the same time that gases are coming out of the planet to feed the atmosphere, the magma ocean is sucking them back into the interior,” said co-author Tim Lichtenberg from the University of Groningen in the Netherlands. “This planet must be much, much more volatile-rich than Earth to explain the observations. It's really like a wet lava ball.”

These are the first results from Webb’s General Observers Program 3860, which involved observing the system continuously for more than 37 hours while TOI-561 b completed nearly four full orbits of the star. The team is currently analyzing the full data set to map the temperature all the way around the planet and narrow down the composition of the atmosphere.

“What’s really exciting is that this new data set is opening up even more questions than it’s answering,” said Teske.

The James Webb Space Telescope is the world’s premier space science observatory. Webb is solving mysteries in our solar system, looking beyond to distant worlds around other stars, and probing the mysterious structures and origins of our universe and our place in it. Webb is an international program led by NASA with its partners, ESA (European Space Agency) and CSA (Canadian Space Agency).

To learn more about Webb, visit:

https://science.nasa.gov/webb

Related Information

Read more: Can Rocky Worlds Orbiting Red Dwarf Stars Maintain Atmospheres?

Explore more: ViewSpace Exoplanet Variety: Atmosphere

Explore more: How to Study Exoplanets: Webb and Challenges

Explore more: How Do We Learn About a Planet’s Atmosphere?

Read more: NASA’s Webb Hints at Possible Atmosphere Surrounding Rocky Exoplanet

articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific discovery using NASA's James Webb Space Telescope: the detection of a thick atmosphere around a rocky exoplanet, TOI-561 b. This finding challenges existing theories about atmospheres on small, close-orbiting planets and expands our understanding of planetary formation and atmospheric retention under extreme conditions. The discovery has broad implications for exoplanet science and the study of planetary atmospheres, representing a meaningful advancement in space exploration.
articles.personality_title: NASA’s Webb Telescope finds thick atmosphere on scorching lava planet
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists have been studying planets outside our solar system, called exoplanets, to learn if they have atmospheres like Earth. Usually, small rocky planets very close to their stars are thought to lose their atmospheres because of intense heat.

**What happened** – Using NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope, researchers observed an exoplanet named TOI-561 b. This planet is about 1.4 times the size of Earth and orbits its star extremely quickly, completing one orbit in less than 11 hours. Despite being so close to its star that its surface is mostly molten lava, the telescope found strong signs that TOI-561 b has a thick atmosphere made of gases. This atmosphere cools the planet’s hot dayside and makes it less dense than expected.

**Impact** – This discovery is important because it shows that even very hot, small planets can hold on to thick atmospheres. It challenges the earlier belief that such planets would be bare rocks. Understanding TOI-561 b’s atmosphere helps scientists learn about how planets form and survive in extreme conditions, especially around older stars with different chemical makeups.

**What's next step** – The research team is now studying more data from the telescope to map the planet’s temperature around its entire surface and learn more about what its atmosphere is made of. This could give new clues about how atmospheres form and change on rocky planets.

**One-sentence takeaway** – NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope has revealed that the ultra-hot exoplanet TOI-561 b has a thick atmosphere, changing what we know about planets close to their stars.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le télescope Webb de la NASA détecte une atmosphère dense autour d’une planète de lave brûlante
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques étudient les planètes en dehors de notre système solaire, appelées exoplanètes, pour savoir si elles possèdent des atmosphères comme la Terre. En général, on pense que les petites planètes rocheuses très proches de leur étoile perdent leur atmosphère à cause de la chaleur intense.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Grâce au télescope spatial James Webb de la NASA, les chercheurs ont observé une exoplanète nommée TOI-561 b. Cette planète fait environ 1,4 fois la taille de la Terre et orbite très rapidement autour de son étoile, en moins de 11 heures. Malgré sa proximité extrême qui fait fondre sa surface en lave, le télescope a détecté des signes forts d’une atmosphère épaisse composée de gaz. Cette atmosphère refroidit le côté jour de la planète et la rend moins dense que prévu.

**Impact** – Cette découverte est importante car elle montre que même les petites planètes très chaudes peuvent garder une atmosphère épaisse. Cela remet en question l’idée que ces planètes seraient des rochers nus. Comprendre l’atmosphère de TOI-561 b aide les scientifiques à mieux connaître la formation et la survie des planètes dans des conditions extrêmes, notamment autour d’étoiles plus vieilles avec une composition chimique différente.

**Prochaine étape** – L’équipe de recherche analyse maintenant plus de données du télescope pour cartographier la température de la planète sur toute sa surface et mieux comprendre la composition de son atmosphère. Cela pourrait apporter de nouveaux indices sur la formation et l’évolution des atmosphères des planètes rocheuses.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – Le télescope spatial James Webb de la NASA a révélé que l’exoplanète ultra-chaude TOI-561 b possède une atmosphère épaisse, changeant notre compréhension des planètes proches de leur étoile.
articles.personality_title_es: El telescopio Webb de la NASA detecta una atmósfera densa en un planeta de lava ardiente
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos estudian planetas fuera de nuestro sistema solar, llamados exoplanetas, para saber si tienen atmósferas como la Tierra. Generalmente, se piensa que los planetas rocosos pequeños muy cerca de sus estrellas pierden sus atmósferas por el calor intenso.

**Qué pasó** – Usando el telescopio espacial James Webb de la NASA, los investigadores observaron un exoplaneta llamado TOI-561 b. Este planeta es aproximadamente 1.4 veces el tamaño de la Tierra y orbita muy rápido alrededor de su estrella, en menos de 11 horas. A pesar de estar tan cerca que su superficie está casi toda en lava fundida, el telescopio encontró señales claras de que TOI-561 b tiene una atmósfera espesa hecha de gases. Esta atmósfera enfría el lado diurno del planeta y lo hace menos denso de lo esperado.

**Impacto** – Este descubrimiento es importante porque muestra que incluso los planetas pequeños y muy calientes pueden mantener atmósferas gruesas. Esto desafía la idea anterior de que esos planetas serían solo rocas desnudas. Entender la atmósfera de TOI-561 b ayuda a los científicos a aprender cómo se forman y sobreviven los planetas en condiciones extremas, especialmente alrededor de estrellas viejas con composiciones químicas diferentes.

**Próximo paso** – El equipo de investigación está analizando más datos del telescopio para mapear la temperatura de todo el planeta y conocer mejor la composición de su atmósfera. Esto podría dar nuevas pistas sobre cómo se forman y cambian las atmósferas en planetas rocosos.

**Conclusión en una frase** – El telescopio espacial James Webb de la NASA ha descubierto que el exoplaneta ultra caliente TOI-561 b tiene una atmósfera espesa, cambiando lo que sabemos sobre planetas cercanos a sus estrellas.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting of a glowing, molten super-Earth with a thick, swirling atmosphere of translucent gases above a vast magma ocean, orbiting closely around a softly radiant star in a dark space background, using natural reds, oranges, and muted blues to evoke intense heat and dynamic atmospheric flow.

articles.title: NASA JPL Unveils Rover Operations Center for Moon, Mars Missions
articles.summary: The center leverages AI along with JPL’s unique infrastructure, unrivaled tools, and years of operations expertise to support industry partners developing future planetary surface missions.   NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Southern California on Wednesday inaugurated its Rover Operations Center (ROC), a center of excellence for current and future surface missions to the Moon and Mars. […]
articles.content:
This video highlights the Rover Operations Center at NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory. A center of excellence for current and future rover, aerial, and other surface missions, the ROC will support partnerships and technology transfer to catalyze the next generation of Moon and Mars surface missions. Credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech

The center leverages AI along with JPL’s unique infrastructure, unrivaled tools, and years of operations expertise to support industry partners developing future planetary surface missions.

NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Southern California on Wednesday inaugurated its Rover Operations Center (ROC), a center of excellence for current and future surface missions to the Moon and Mars. During the launch event, leaders from the commercial space and AI industries toured the facilities, participated in working sessions with JPL mission teams, and learned more about the first-ever use of generative AI by NASA’s Perseverance Mars rover team to create future routes for the robotic explorer.

The center was established to integrate and innovate across JPL’s planetary surface missions while simultaneously forging strategic partnerships with industry and academia to advance U.S. interests in the burgeoning space economy. The center builds on JPL’s 30-plus years of experience developing and operating Mars surface missions, including humanity’s only helicopter to fly at Mars as well as the only two active planetary surface missions.

“The Rover Operations Center is a force multiplier,” said JPL Director Dave Gallagher. “It integrates decades of specialized knowledge with powerful new tools, and exports that knowledge through partnerships to catalyze the next generation of Moon and Mars surface missions. As NASA’s federally funded research and development center, we are chartered to do exactly this type of work — to increase the cadence, the efficiency, and the impact for our transformative NASA missions and to support the commercial space market as they take their own giant leaps.”

Rover prototype ERNEST (Exploration Rover for Navigating Extreme Sloped Terrain) demonstrates some of its advanced mobility and autonomy capabilities in JPL’s Mars Yard. NASA/JPL-Caltech

Genesis of ROC

Through decades of successful Mars rover missions, JPL has continuously improved the unique autonomy, robotic capabilities, and best practices that have been demanded by increasingly complex robotic explorers. The ROC offers an accessible centralized structure to facilitate future exploration efforts.

“Our rovers are lasting longer and are more sophisticated than ever before. The scientific stakes are high, as we have just witnessed with the discovery of a potential biosignature in Jezero Crater by the Perseverance mission. We are starting down a decade of unprecedented civil and commercial exploration at the Moon, which will require robotic systems to assist astronauts and support lunar infrastructure,” said Matt Wallace, who heads JPL’s Exploration Systems Office. “Mobile vehicles like rovers, helicopters, and drones are the most dynamic and challenging assets we operate. It’s time to take our game up a notch and bring everybody we can with us.”

Michael Thelen of JPL’s Exploration Systems Office discusses the newly inaugurated Rover Operations Center in JPL’s historic Space Flight Operations Facility on Dec. 10. NASA/JPL-Caltech

Future forward

A key focus of the ROC is on the more rapid infusion of higher-level autonomy into surface missions through partnerships with the AI and commercial space industries. The objective is to catalyze change to deliver next-generation science and exploration capabilities for the nation and NASA.

As NASA’s only federally funded research and development center, JPL has been evolving vehicle autonomy since the 1990s, when JPL began developing Sojourner, the first rover on another planet. Improvements to vehicle independence over the years have included the evolution of autonomy in sampling activities, driving, and science-target selection. Most recently, those improvements have extended to the development of Perseverance’s ability to autonomously schedule and execute many commanded energy-intensive activities, like keeping warm at night, as it sees fit. This capability allows the rover to conserve power, which it can reallocate in real time to perform more science or longer drives.

With the explosion of AI capabilities, the ROC rover team is leaving no Mars stone unturned in the hunt for future efficiencies.

“We had a small team complete a ‘three-week challenge,’ applying generative AI to a few of our operational use cases. During this challenge, it became clear there are many opportunities for AI infusion that can supercharge our capabilities,” said Jennifer Trosper, ROC program manager at JPL. “With these new partnerships, together we will infuse AI into operations to path-find the next generation of capabilities for science and exploration.”

Håvard Grip, chief pilot of NASA’s Mars Ingenuity Helicopter — the only aircraft to fly on another planet — offers insights into aerial exploration of the Red Planet at the lab’s 25-Foot Space Simulator, which subjects spacecraft to the harsh conditions of space.

During the ROC’s inauguration, attendees toured JPL operations facilities, including where the rover drivers plan their next routes. They also visited JPL’s historic Mars Yard, which reproduces Martian terrain to test rover capabilities, and the massive 25-Foot Space Simulator that has tested spacecraft from Voyagers 1 and 2 to Perseverance to America’s next generation of lunar landers. A panel discussion explored the historical value of rovers and aerial systems like the Ingenuity Mars Helicopter in planetary surface exploration. Also discussed was the promise of a new public-private partnership opportunity across a virtual network of operational missions.

Attendees were briefed on tiered engagement options for partners, from mission architecture support to autonomy integration, testing, and operations. These opportunities extend to science and human precursor robotic missions, as well as to human-robotic interaction and spacewalks for astronauts on the Moon and Mars.

A highlight for event participants came when the Perseverance team showcased how the ROC’s generative AI can assist rover planners in creating future routes for the rover. The AI analyzed high-resolution orbital images of Jezero Crater and other relevant data and then generated waypoints that kept Perseverance away from hazardous terrain.

Managed for NASA by Caltech, JPL is the home of the Rover Operations Center (ROC).

To learn more about the ROC, visit:

https://www.jpl.nasa.gov/roc

News Media Contact

DC Agle

Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Pasadena, Calif.

818-393-9011

agle@jpl.nasa.gov

2025-137
articles.reasoning: The article reports the inauguration of NASA JPL's Rover Operations Center, a significant advancement that leverages AI and decades of expertise to enhance robotic missions on the Moon and Mars. This center supports broad future space exploration efforts, fosters public-private partnerships, and integrates cutting-edge autonomy technologies, representing a meaningful and inspiring development in space exploration with wide-reaching impact.
articles.personality_title: NASA's new Rover Operations Center boosts Moon and Mars missions with AI
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL) has long led robotic missions on Mars, including operating rovers and the Mars helicopter. To support future exploration on the Moon and Mars, JPL created a new center focused on rover and surface mission operations.

**What happened** – On December 10, 2024, JPL officially opened the Rover Operations Center (ROC) in Southern California. The ROC uses artificial intelligence (AI), advanced tools, and JPL’s 30-plus years of Mars experience to help plan and run current and future robotic missions. During the opening event, industry and AI experts toured the facility, learned about ROC’s role, and saw how AI helps the Perseverance rover choose safe routes on Mars.

**Impact** – The ROC is important because it brings together JPL’s knowledge and new AI technology to improve how robotic explorers work on other planets. For example, Perseverance can now use AI to plan its path around dangerous terrain on Mars, making missions safer and more efficient. The center also supports partnerships with companies and universities to develop better robots for space, helping future Moon and Mars missions.

**What's next step** – JPL will continue to add more AI features to rover operations and work closely with commercial and academic partners. This will speed up the development of smarter robots that can explore, assist astronauts, and build infrastructure on the Moon and Mars. The ROC will also support new missions and help test technologies in JPL’s Mars-like testing grounds.

**One-sentence takeaway** – NASA’s new Rover Operations Center combines AI and deep expertise to improve robotic exploration on the Moon and Mars, paving the way for smarter and safer space missions.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le nouveau centre d’opérations des rovers de la NASA renforce les missions lunaires et martiennes grâce à l’IA
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL) de la NASA dirige depuis longtemps des missions robotiques sur Mars, notamment avec des rovers et l’hélicoptère martien. Pour soutenir l’exploration future de la Lune et de Mars, le JPL a créé un nouveau centre dédié aux opérations des rovers et des missions de surface.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le 10 décembre 2024, le JPL a officiellement inauguré le Rover Operations Center (ROC) en Californie du Sud. Le ROC utilise l’intelligence artificielle (IA), des outils avancés et plus de 30 ans d’expérience sur Mars pour aider à planifier et gérer les missions robotiques actuelles et futures. Lors de l’inauguration, des experts de l’industrie et de l’IA ont visité le centre et découvert comment l’IA aide le rover Perseverance à choisir des routes sûres sur Mars.

**Impact** – Le ROC est important car il réunit le savoir-faire du JPL et les nouvelles technologies d’IA pour améliorer le travail des robots explorateurs sur d’autres planètes. Par exemple, Perseverance utilise maintenant l’IA pour planifier son chemin en évitant les terrains dangereux, rendant les missions plus sûres et efficaces. Le centre soutient aussi les partenariats avec des entreprises et des universités pour développer de meilleurs robots spatiaux pour la Lune et Mars.

**Étape suivante** – Le JPL continuera d’ajouter des fonctions d’IA aux opérations des rovers et travaillera étroitement avec des partenaires commerciaux et universitaires. Cela accélérera le développement de robots plus intelligents capables d’explorer, d’aider les astronautes et de construire des infrastructures sur la Lune et Mars. Le ROC soutiendra aussi de nouvelles missions et testera des technologies dans des terrains d’essai similaires à Mars.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Le nouveau centre d’opérations des rovers de la NASA combine IA et expertise pour améliorer l’exploration robotique sur la Lune et Mars, ouvrant la voie à des missions spatiales plus intelligentes et sûres.
articles.personality_title_es: El nuevo Centro de Operaciones de Rovers de la NASA impulsa las misiones a la Luna y Marte con IA
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El Laboratorio de Propulsión a Chorro (JPL) de la NASA ha liderado durante mucho tiempo misiones robóticas en Marte, incluyendo la operación de rovers y el helicóptero marciano. Para apoyar futuras exploraciones en la Luna y Marte, el JPL creó un nuevo centro enfocado en operaciones de rovers y misiones en superficie.

**Qué pasó** – El 10 de diciembre de 2024, el JPL inauguró oficialmente el Centro de Operaciones de Rovers (ROC) en el sur de California. El ROC utiliza inteligencia artificial (IA), herramientas avanzadas y más de 30 años de experiencia en Marte para ayudar a planificar y manejar misiones robóticas actuales y futuras. Durante la apertura, expertos de la industria y de IA visitaron las instalaciones y vieron cómo la IA ayuda al rover Perseverance a elegir rutas seguras en Marte.

**Impacto** – El ROC es importante porque reúne el conocimiento del JPL y la nueva tecnología de IA para mejorar el trabajo de los exploradores robóticos en otros planetas. Por ejemplo, Perseverance ahora puede usar IA para planear su camino evitando terrenos peligrosos, haciendo las misiones más seguras y eficientes. El centro también apoya asociaciones con empresas y universidades para desarrollar mejores robots para la Luna y Marte.

**Próximo paso** – El JPL seguirá añadiendo más funciones de IA a las operaciones de los rovers y trabajará estrechamente con socios comerciales y académicos. Esto acelerará el desarrollo de robots más inteligentes que puedan explorar, ayudar a los astronautas y construir infraestructura en la Luna y Marte. El ROC también apoyará nuevas misiones y probará tecnologías en terrenos similares a Marte.

**Resumen en una frase** – El nuevo Centro de Operaciones de Rovers de la NASA combina IA y experiencia para mejorar la exploración robótica en la Luna y Marte, preparando el camino para misiones espaciales más inteligentes y seguras.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting of a futuristic mission control room filled with glowing screens displaying stylized maps of the Moon and Mars, with abstract robotic rovers and a small helicopter silhouette navigating rocky, cratered landscapes, all rendered in soft natural earth tones and muted reds, symbolizing advanced AI-driven exploration and collaboration between technology and space.

articles.title: Earth and solar system may have been shaped by nearby exploding star
articles.summary: A new explanation for the solar system's radioactive elements suggests Earth-like planets might be found orbiting up to 50 per cent of sun-like stars
articles.content:
A new explanation for the solar system's radioactive elements suggests Earth-like planets might be found orbiting up to 50 per cent of sun-like stars

SNR 0519, the remnant of a supernova that exploded about 600 years ago Claude Cornen/ESA/Hubble & NASA

Earth may owe some of its properties to a nearby star that blew up just as the solar system was forming. This pattern, which saw a supernova bubble envelop the sun and shower it with cosmic rays, may be ubiquitous across the galaxy – implying there could be a far greater number of Earth-like planets than previously thought.

We know, thanks to ancient meteorite samples, that the solar system used to be filled with heat-producing radioactive elements that quickly decayed. The heat from these elements drove off large amounts of water from the space rocks and comets that came together to form Earth, ensuring the planet had the right amount of water for life to later develop.

Advertisement

It is unclear, however, how these elements reached the solar system. Many of them are commonly found in supernova explosions, but simulations of close-by supernovae have struggled to produce the exact ratios of radioactive elements inferred from meteorite samples to have been present in the early solar system. One problem is that these nearby blasts may also have been so powerful that they would have blown apart the fragile early solar system before any planets had formed.

Now, Ryo Sawada at the University of Tokyo in Japan and his colleagues have found that a supernova could have provided the necessary radioactive ingredients for Earth without upsetting the planet formation process, as long as it was slightly further away.

In their model, a supernova that is around 3 light years from the solar system could produce the required radioactive elements in a two-stage process. Some, such as radioactive aluminium and manganese, would be produced directly in the supernova and then travel on shock waves from the exploded star to reach the solar system.

Free newsletter Sign up to Launchpad Bring the galaxy to your inbox every month, with the latest space news, launches and astronomical occurrences from New Scientist’s Leah Crane. Sign up to newsletter

Then, high-energy particles called cosmic rays emanating from the supernova would follow behind these shock waves and hit other atoms in the solar system’s still-forming disc of gas, dust and rocks, a process that would produce the remaining radioactive elements needed, such as beryllium and calcium. “Previous models of solar system formation focused only on the injection of matter. I realised we were ignoring the high-energy particles,” says Sawada. “I thought, ‘What if the young solar system was simply engulfed in this particle bath?’”

Because this process works with a supernova that is further away than previous studies, Sawada and his team estimate that between 10 to 50 per cent of sun-like star and planetary systems could have been seeded with radioactive elements in this way and produced planets with Earth-like abundances of water. For previous models, with close-by supernovae, being hit was “like winning the lottery”, says Sawada. But moving the supernova further away implies that “the recipe for Earth is likely not a rare accident, but a universal process happening all over the galaxy,” he says.

“It’s quite novel, because it’s a fine balance between destruction and creation,” says Cosimo Inserra at Cardiff University, UK. “You need the right elements and the right distance.”

If this mechanism is correct, it could help guide future searches for Earth-like planets by planned telescopes like NASA’s Habitable Worlds Observatory, by looking for traces of ancient supernovae and finding star systems that were close to them at the time, says Inserra.
articles.reasoning: The article presents a significant scientific breakthrough explaining how Earth-like planets with suitable water content may be common in the galaxy due to a supernova mechanism. This discovery has broad implications for understanding planet formation and guiding future searches for habitable worlds, offering hopeful insights into the prevalence of potentially life-supporting planets.
articles.personality_title: Nearby supernova may have helped form Earth-like planets around many stars
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists have long wondered how Earth got its radioactive elements, which helped shape its water content and conditions for life. These elements likely came from a nearby exploding star, or supernova, when the solar system was forming.

**What happened** – Researchers led by Ryo Sawada from the University of Tokyo developed a new model showing that a supernova about 3 light years away could have sent radioactive elements and cosmic rays to the early solar system. This process created the right amounts of elements like aluminum, manganese, beryllium, and calcium without destroying the forming planets.

**Impact** – This idea changes previous thinking that a supernova had to be very close, which would have damaged the solar system. Instead, the supernova could be farther away, making it more likely that many other sun-like stars also received these elements. Scientists now estimate that 10 to 50 percent of stars similar to the sun might have Earth-like planets with the right water content.

**What’s next step** – The discovery helps guide future space telescopes, like NASA’s Habitable Worlds Observatory, to look for star systems that were near supernovae long ago. This will improve the search for planets that might support life.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A supernova at the right distance likely gave Earth and many other planets the radioactive elements needed to form with life-supporting water.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une supernova proche pourrait avoir aidé à former des planètes semblables à la Terre autour de nombreuses étoiles
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques se demandent depuis longtemps comment la Terre a obtenu ses éléments radioactifs, qui ont aidé à façonner sa teneur en eau et ses conditions pour la vie. Ces éléments proviendraient d’une étoile proche en explosion, une supernova, au moment où le système solaire se formait.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Une équipe menée par Ryo Sawada de l’Université de Tokyo a proposé un nouveau modèle montrant qu’une supernova située à environ 3 années-lumière aurait pu envoyer des éléments radioactifs et des rayons cosmiques vers le jeune système solaire. Ce processus a créé les bonnes quantités d’éléments comme l’aluminium, le manganèse, le béryllium et le calcium, sans détruire les planètes en formation.

**Impact** – Cette idée change la pensée précédente selon laquelle une supernova devait être très proche, ce qui aurait endommagé le système solaire. Au lieu de cela, la supernova pouvait être plus éloignée, ce qui rend plus probable que de nombreuses autres étoiles semblables au Soleil aient aussi reçu ces éléments. Les scientifiques estiment maintenant que 10 à 50 % des étoiles similaires au Soleil pourraient avoir des planètes semblables à la Terre avec la bonne teneur en eau.

**Prochaine étape** – Cette découverte aidera à orienter les futurs télescopes spatiaux, comme le Habitable Worlds Observatory de la NASA, pour chercher des systèmes stellaires qui étaient proches de supernovas il y a longtemps. Cela améliorera la recherche de planètes pouvant abriter la vie.

**En une phrase** – Une supernova à la bonne distance a probablement donné à la Terre et à beaucoup d’autres planètes les éléments radioactifs nécessaires pour se former avec de l’eau favorable à la vie.
articles.personality_title_es: Una supernova cercana pudo haber ayudado a formar planetas similares a la Tierra alrededor de muchas estrellas
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos han querido saber durante mucho tiempo cómo la Tierra obtuvo sus elementos radiactivos, que ayudaron a formar su contenido de agua y las condiciones para la vida. Estos elementos probablemente vinieron de una estrella cercana que explotó, una supernova, cuando se formaba el sistema solar.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores liderados por Ryo Sawada de la Universidad de Tokio crearon un nuevo modelo que muestra que una supernova a unos 3 años luz pudo enviar elementos radiactivos y rayos cósmicos al sistema solar joven. Este proceso produjo las cantidades correctas de elementos como aluminio, manganeso, berilio y calcio sin destruir los planetas en formación.

**Impacto** – Esta idea cambia el pensamiento anterior de que la supernova tenía que estar muy cerca, lo que habría dañado el sistema solar. En cambio, la supernova podía estar más lejos, lo que hace más probable que muchas otras estrellas parecidas al sol también recibieran estos elementos. Ahora se estima que entre el 10 y el 50 por ciento de las estrellas similares al sol podrían tener planetas con agua y características parecidas a la Tierra.

**Próximo paso** – Este descubrimiento ayudará a futuros telescopios espaciales, como el Habitable Worlds Observatory de la NASA, a buscar sistemas estelares que estuvieron cerca de supernovas antiguas. Esto mejorará la búsqueda de planetas que puedan tener vida.

**Una frase para recordar** – Una supernova a la distancia adecuada probablemente dio a la Tierra y a muchos otros planetas los elementos radiactivos necesarios para formarse con agua que permite la vida.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm-toned painting of a glowing young solar system encased within a gentle, radiant cosmic bubble formed by a distant supernova explosion, with swirling shock waves and streams of shimmering cosmic rays enveloping the swirling disc of gas, dust, and forming planets—symbolizing the delicate balance of creation and energy seeding Earth-like worlds across the galaxy.

articles.title: NASA’s Chandra Finds Small Galaxies May Buck the Black Hole Trend
articles.summary: Most smaller galaxies may not have supermassive black holes in their centers, according to a recent  study using NASA’s Chandra X-ray Observatory. This contrasts with the common idea that nearly every galaxy has one of these giant black holes within their cores, as NASA leads the world in exploring how our universe works. A team […]
articles.content:
NGC 6278 and PGC 039620 are two galaxies from a sample of 1,600 that were searched for the presence of supermassive black holes. These images represent the results of a study that suggests that smaller galaxies do not contain supermassive black holes nearly as often as larger galaxies do. The study analyzed over 1,600 galaxies that have been observed with Chandra over two decades. Certain X-ray signatures indicate the presence of supermassive black holes. The study indicates that most smaller galaxies like PGC 03620, shown here in both X-rays from Chandra and optical light images from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey, likely do not have supermassive black holes in their centers. In contrast, NGC 6278, which is roughly the same size as the Milky Way, and most other large galaxies in the sample show evidence for giant black holes within their cores. X-ray: NASA/CXC/SAO/F. Zou et al.; Optical: SDSS; Image Processing: NASA/CXC/SAO/N. Wolk

Most smaller galaxies may not have supermassive black holes in their centers, according to a recent study using NASA’s Chandra X-ray Observatory. This contrasts with the common idea that nearly every galaxy has one of these giant black holes within their cores, as NASA leads the world in exploring how our universe works.

A team of astronomers used data from over 1,600 galaxies collected in more than two decades of the Chandra mission. The researchers looked at galaxies ranging in heft from over ten times the mass of the Milky Way down to dwarf galaxies, which have stellar masses less than a few percent of that of our home galaxy. A paper describing these results has been published in The Astrophysical Journal and is available here https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.05252.

The team has reported that only about 30% of dwarf galaxies likely contain supermassive black holes.

“It’s important to get an accurate black hole head count in these smaller galaxies,” said Fan Zou of the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor, who led the study. “It’s more than just bookkeeping. Our study gives clues about how supermassive black holes are born. It also provides crucial hints about how often black hole signatures in dwarf galaxies can be found with new or future telescopes.”

As material falls onto black holes, it is heated by friction and produces X-rays. Many of the massive galaxies in the study contain bright X-ray sources in their centers, a clear signature of supermassive black holes in their centers. The team concluded that more than 90% of massive galaxies – including those with the mass of the Milky Way – contain supermassive black holes.

However, smaller galaxies in the study usually did not have these unambiguous black hole signals. Galaxies with masses less than three billion Suns – about the mass of the Large Magellanic Cloud, a close neighbor to the Milky Way – usually do not contain bright X-ray sources in their centers.

The researchers considered two possible explanations for this lack of X-ray sources. The first is that the fraction of galaxies containing massive black holes is much lower for these less massive galaxies. The second is the amount of X-rays produced by matter falling onto these black holes is so faint that Chandra cannot detect it.

“We think, based on our analysis of the Chandra data, that there really are fewer black holes in these smaller galaxies than in their larger counterparts,” said Elena Gallo, a co-author also from the University of Michigan.

To reach their conclusion, Zou and his colleagues considered both possibilities for the lack of X-ray sources in small galaxies in their large Chandra sample. The amount of gas falling onto a black hole determines how bright or faint they are in X-rays. Because smaller black holes are expected to pull in less gas than larger black holes, they should be fainter in X-rays and often not detectable. The researchers confirmed this expectation.

However, they found that an additional deficit of X-ray sources is seen in less massive galaxies beyond the expected decline from decreases in the amount of gas falling inwards. This additional deficit can be accounted for if many of the low-mass galaxies simply don’t have any black holes at their centers. The team’s conclusion was that the drop in X-ray detections in lower mass galaxies reflects a true decrease in the number of black holes located in these galaxies.

This result could have important implications for understanding how supermassive black holes form. There are two main ideas: In the first, a giant gas cloud directly collapses into a black hole, which contains thousands of times the Sun’s mass from the start. The other idea is that supermassive black holes instead come from much smaller black holes, created when massive stars collapse.

“The formation of big black holes is expected to be rarer, in the sense that it occurs preferentially in the most massive galaxies being formed, so that would explain why we don’t find black holes in all the smaller galaxies,” said co-author Anil Seth of the University of Utah.

This study supports the theory where giant black holes are born already weighing several thousand times the Sun’s mass. If the other idea were true, the researchers said they would have expected smaller galaxies to likely have the same fraction of black holes as larger ones.

This result also could have important implications for the rates of black hole mergers from the collisions of dwarf galaxies. A much lower number of black holes would result in fewer sources of gravitational waves to be detected in the future by the Laser Interferometer Space Antenna. The number of black holes tearing stars apart in dwarf galaxies will also be smaller.

NASA’s Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Alabama, manages the Chandra program. The Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory’s Chandra X-ray Center controls science operations from Cambridge, Massachusetts, and flight operations from Burlington, Massachusetts.

To learn more about Chandra, visit:

https://science.nasa.gov/chandra



Read more from NASA’s Chandra X-ray Observatory

Learn more about the Chandra X-ray Observatory and its mission here:

https://www.nasa.gov/chandra

https://chandra.si.edu

News Media Contact

Megan Watzke

Chandra X-ray Center

Cambridge, Mass.

617-496-7998

mwatzke@cfa.harvard.edu

Corinne Beckinger

Marshall Space Flight Center, Huntsville, Alabama

256-544-0034

corinne.m.beckinger@nasa.gov
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific discovery about the distribution of supermassive black holes in galaxies, challenging previous assumptions and providing new insights into black hole formation. The study uses extensive data from NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory, impacting our understanding of galaxy evolution and future gravitational wave research, which has broad relevance for the scientific community and the public interested in space exploration.
articles.personality_title: NASA study finds many small galaxies likely lack supermassive black holes
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists have long believed that most galaxies, including small ones, contain supermassive black holes at their centers. These black holes are extremely heavy objects millions or billions of times the mass of the Sun. NASA’s Chandra X-ray Observatory has been collecting data on thousands of galaxies for over 20 years.

**What happened** – A team of astronomers analyzed data from more than 1,600 galaxies using Chandra’s X-ray observations. They found that while large galaxies, like the Milky Way, almost always have supermassive black holes, most smaller galaxies do not show signs of having them. The study showed that only about 30% of small galaxies, called dwarf galaxies, likely contain these black holes.

**Impact** – This discovery challenges the idea that every galaxy has a supermassive black hole. It suggests that black holes form differently depending on the galaxy size. The findings support the theory that big black holes start very large from the beginning, rather than growing slowly from smaller stars. This changes how scientists think about galaxy development and will affect predictions for detecting black hole collisions and gravitational waves.

**What's next step** – Researchers will use this information to improve models of how black holes form and grow. Future telescopes and observatories will look for even fainter signs of black holes in small galaxies to confirm these results. This work will help scientists better understand the role of black holes in the universe and improve searches for gravitational waves from merging black holes.

**One-sentence takeaway** – New research using NASA’s Chandra data shows that most small galaxies do not have supermassive black holes, offering fresh clues about how these cosmic giants form and evolve.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une étude de la NASA révèle que de nombreuses petites galaxies n'ont probablement pas de trous noirs supermassifs
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques pensaient que la plupart des galaxies, même les petites, contenaient des trous noirs supermassifs en leur centre. Ces trous noirs sont des objets très lourds, des millions ou des milliards de fois la masse du Soleil. L'observatoire à rayons X Chandra de la NASA collecte des données sur des milliers de galaxies depuis plus de 20 ans.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Une équipe d'astronomes a analysé les données de plus de 1 600 galaxies grâce aux observations en rayons X de Chandra. Ils ont découvert que, tandis que les grandes galaxies, comme la Voie lactée, ont presque toujours des trous noirs supermassifs, la plupart des petites galaxies n'en montrent pas de signes. L'étude indique que seulement environ 30 % des petites galaxies, appelées galaxies naines, contiennent probablement ces trous noirs.

**Impact** – Cette découverte remet en question l'idée que chaque galaxie possède un trou noir supermassif. Elle suggère que la formation des trous noirs dépend de la taille de la galaxie. Les résultats appuient la théorie selon laquelle les grands trous noirs naissent déjà très gros, plutôt que de grandir lentement à partir de petites étoiles. Cela change la vision des scientifiques sur le développement des galaxies et influencera les prévisions pour détecter les collisions de trous noirs et les ondes gravitationnelles.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs vont utiliser ces informations pour améliorer les modèles de formation et de croissance des trous noirs. Les futurs télescopes et observatoires chercheront des signes encore plus faibles de trous noirs dans les petites galaxies pour confirmer ces résultats. Ce travail aidera à mieux comprendre le rôle des trous noirs dans l'univers et à améliorer la recherche des ondes gravitationnelles issues de la fusion des trous noirs.

**En une phrase** – Une nouvelle recherche utilisant les données de Chandra de la NASA montre que la plupart des petites galaxies n'ont pas de trous noirs supermassifs, apportant de nouvelles pistes sur la formation et l'évolution de ces géants cosmiques.
articles.personality_title_es: Estudio de la NASA encuentra que muchas galaxias pequeñas probablemente no tienen agujeros negros supermasivos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos han pensado durante mucho tiempo que la mayoría de las galaxias, incluidas las pequeñas, tienen agujeros negros supermasivos en su centro. Estos agujeros negros son objetos extremadamente pesados, millones o miles de millones de veces la masa del Sol. El Observatorio de rayos X Chandra de la NASA ha estado recolectando datos de miles de galaxias durante más de 20 años.

**Qué pasó** – Un equipo de astrónomos analizó datos de más de 1,600 galaxias usando las observaciones en rayos X de Chandra. Encontraron que, mientras las galaxias grandes, como la Vía Láctea, casi siempre tienen agujeros negros supermasivos, la mayoría de las galaxias pequeñas no muestran señales de tenerlos. El estudio mostró que solo alrededor del 30% de las galaxias pequeñas, llamadas galaxias enanas, probablemente contienen estos agujeros negros.

**Impacto** – Este descubrimiento desafía la idea de que todas las galaxias tienen un agujero negro supermasivo. Sugiere que los agujeros negros se forman de manera diferente según el tamaño de la galaxia. Los resultados apoyan la teoría de que los agujeros negros grandes nacen ya muy grandes, en lugar de crecer lentamente a partir de estrellas más pequeñas. Esto cambia la forma en que los científicos piensan sobre el desarrollo de las galaxias y afectará las predicciones para detectar colisiones de agujeros negros y ondas gravitacionales.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores usarán esta información para mejorar los modelos de cómo se forman y crecen los agujeros negros. Los futuros telescopios y observatorios buscarán señales aún más débiles de agujeros negros en galaxias pequeñas para confirmar estos resultados. Este trabajo ayudará a los científicos a entender mejor el papel de los agujeros negros en el universo y a mejorar la búsqueda de ondas gravitacionales de fusiones de agujeros negros.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Una nueva investigación con datos de Chandra de la NASA muestra que la mayoría de las galaxias pequeñas no tienen agujeros negros supermasivos, brindando nuevas pistas sobre cómo se forman y evolucionan estos gigantes cósmicos.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting showing two contrasting galaxies side by side: a large spiral galaxy glowing softly with a bright, radiant core symbolizing a supermassive black hole emitting gentle X-ray light, and a smaller, dimmer dwarf galaxy with a faint or absent core, surrounded by subtle cosmic dust and stars, all rendered in natural, soft blues, purples, and warm earth tones.
